title-group.article-title: Research on strategies for enhancing system security resilience of prefabricated building engineering

abstract.p: With the construction industry’s deepening development towards digitalization, intelligentization, greening, and industrialization, prefabricated building is poised for significant promotion due to its characteristics of energy efficiency, environmental friendliness, rapid progress, and high quality. Current safety management models for prefabricated construction primarily focus on preventing safety accidents, lacking a holistic, systematic analysis of the system’s comprehensive capability when subjected to risk disturbances. This study adopts a resilience perspective, focusing on the safety resilience of prefabricated construction engineering systems. Utilizing accident case studies and academic literature as sources, it preliminarily identifies 24 influencing factors of safety resilience based on the four types of resilience. The rationality of the indicator system is validated through confirmatory factor analysis, including structural validity, convergent validity, and discriminant validity. Based on the screened and validated safety resilience indicator system, a Bayesian Network model for the safety resilience of prefabricated construction engineering is established. Through forward causal inference, backward diagnostic inference, and sensitivity analysis within the Bayesian Network model, critical influencing pathways and sensitive nodes are identified. Targeted countermeasures and suggestions to enhance the safety resilience of prefabricated construction engineering systems are proposed. This approach can effectively improve the system’s risk resistance capability and post-disaster rapid recovery capacity, thereby strengthening its overall safety resilience.

funding-source.institution: Scientific Research Project of Hebei Provincial Department of Education

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Compared to traditional construction methods, prefabricated construction offers distinct advantages in energy efficiency, environmental sustainability, accelerated project timelines, and enhanced quality control. It significantly reduces labor requirements and mitigates safety risks1,2. The development of digital technology has enabled information transmission and collaborative interaction in the design, manufacturing, assembly, and operation and maintenance of building components, achieving precise geometric control and effectively improving the quality, progress, and environmental benefits of prefabricated buildings3,4.The imperative for green and sustainable development has provided clearer strategic direction for the construction industry, accelerating the adoption and advancement of prefabricated building systems.However, inherent limitations in design sophistication and construction techniques associated with prefabricated construction have led to the emergence of novel safety management challenges5,6. Consequently, conventional safety and risk prevention paradigms are increasingly inadequate for addressing the safety management requirements of prefabricated construction engineering7.In recent years, safety resilience theory—an interdisciplinary conceptual framework emerging from multiple fields has been progressively applied across diverse domains including urban planning, ecological management, disaster risk reduction, and socio-economic systems, yielding substantial research advancements8. A systematic investigation of safety issues through the lens of resilience theory offers a novel methodological approach for safety management in prefabricated construction engineering.

Currently, domestic and international scholars predominantly investigate safety management in prefabricated construction from a risk perspective, with research adopting a resilience lens remaining relatively scarce. Regarding safety management and evaluation in prefabricated construction: Song LL identified safety risk factors through expert interviews and validated the efficient propagation and diffusion of these risks9.Fard MM, et al. analyzed 125 prefabricated construction-related accidents, finding that safety assessments during the manufacturing and on-site phases within prefabricated construction departments can serve as a starting point for enhancing safety performance10.Song YH et al. evaluated a lifting operation risk model for prefabricated buildings based on the Human Factors Analysis and Classification System (HFACS)11.Yang and Li (2023) utilized the bidirectional inference capability of Dynamic Bayesian Networks (DBNs) to identify critical risk factors leading to lifting accidents12.Li and Zhang (2023) et al. conducted quantitative analysis and assessment of safety risk factors using a Bayesian Network (BN) algorithm, improving the identification and analysis capabilities for safety risks in prefabricated construction projects13.He and Tian (2023) applied the Decision-Making Trial and Evaluation Laboratory (DEMATEL) method to determine the importance ranking of safety risk factors based on the analysis of numerous prefabricated construction accident cases14.Li and Chen (2022) developed a safety evaluation model for prefabricated construction using an improved Technique for Order Preference by Similarity to Ideal Solution (TOPSIS) method based on entropy-weighted Best-Worst Method (BWM)15.Wang, et al.(2022) performed safety risk assessments for prefabricated construction based on the IM-FCM method16.Fan et al. (2022) conducted safety risk assessment research on prefabricated construction models using game theory-regret theory17.Wang, et al.(2022) carried out safety risk analysis for lifting operations in prefabricated construction based on System-Theoretic Process Analysis (STPA) and fuzzy Bayesian Networks18.Chang, Yan, and Li (2018) constructed system dynamics flowcharts for prefabricated construction safety risks to facilitate safety risk analysis and evaluation19.Bao developed a safety control system and employed evaluation methods to verify its effectiveness for safety management in prefabricated construction20.Regarding system safety resilience: Trinh, MT et al. examined the interactive effects of safety resilience culture and project complexity on safety performance in construction projects21.Shi-Zhi Chen et al. proposed a Prior Knowledge-integrated Neural Network (PKNN) to achieve efficient structural seismic response prediction and low-computational-cost seismic safety assessment, enhancing system safety resilience22. De-Cheng Feng et al. proposed a rapid assessment method for overall damage level of buildings after earthquakes based on component images and deep learning, improving safety recovery resilience23.Song (2023) et al. introduced resilience theory into the safety operation management of water conservancy engineering projects24.Sun (2020) et al., utilizing factor analysis, found that information management plays the most significant role in enhancing engineering safety resilience throughout the entire accident process, particularly when the complex engineering system (composed of human, material, and informational components) is subjected to disturbances from the external environment25.Tang (2023) et al. conducted a safety resilience evaluation of metro station fires based on an improved variable-weight matter-element extension (MVMEE) model, incorporating dimensions such as “4M1E”26.

Based on the above analysis, few scholars have conducted a systematic analysis of the whole-process safety management of prefabricated buildings from the perspective of resilience. This study, grounded in the perspective of resilience, introduces the theory of safety resilience into the safety management model of prefabricated building projects, exploring its safety resilience during implementation27.This theoretically enriches the safety management of prefabricated building projects and effectively enables prefabricated building projects to better predict, respond to, quickly recover from, and learn from risk disturbances in future safety management.

sec.title: Literature review method, case analysis method, and Delphi method
sec.p: The literature review method and case analysis method involve analyzing recent accident cases involving casualties in prefabricated construction projects, and combining this with relevant literature and management standards on safety management of prefabricated construction projects, to identify factors affecting safety resilience.This study initially conducted a comprehensive and systematic analysis of prefabricated construction-related literature, national standards, and safety accident case studies. Through this process, manifestations of risk disturbances within prefabricated construction engineering systems were identified, culminated in the compilation of preliminary safety resilience influencing factors. Then, through the Delphi method, a Delphi expert group consisting of 22 experts and scholars with at least 3 years of work experience in construction project management, construction site management, safety management, etc., from construction units, design units, construction units, engineering consulting units, and research institutes, was invited to rate the importance of influencing factors using the Likert five-point scale. This Delphi method underwent two rounds of scoring. In the first round, survey questionnaires were distributed to the experts, asking them to rate the influencing factors. In the second round, the results from the first round were summarized and fed back to the experts, inviting them to make further choices and judgments.

sec.title: Confirmatory factor analysis
sec.p: CFA (Confirmatory Factor Analysis) is a statistical methodology employed to validate the structural relationships within theoretical models, specifically examining the associations between latent constructs and their observed indicator variables. Unlike exploratory approaches, CFA tests a priori theoretical assumptions regarding measurement structures, focusing on assessing the goodness-of-fit of specified theoretical models. In this research, CFA is utilized to empirically validate the structural rationality of the identified safety resilience influencing factors.

To empirically validate the rationality of the safety resilience indicator system, this study employed a questionnaire survey method to conduct Confirmatory Factor Analysis on the preliminarily identified indicators. The resilience categories were treated as latent constructs, while the influencing factors served as observed variables. Systematically designed measurement items, assessed using a five-point Likert scale to gauge perceived impact levels, formed the core of the questionnaire.The survey specifically targeted practicing professionals engaged in construction project management, on-site construction management, and safety management roles within: Construction developers, Design institutes, Contracting organizations, Supervision companies, Related entities.Utilizing a combined online and offline distribution approach, 274 questionnaires were successfully collected. Following data screening, 252 valid responses were retained, yielding a high valid response rate of 91.97%.
Descriptive Statistical Analysis.
Regarding the educational background of the surveyed individuals, 3.17% have an education level below high school (technical secondary school), 46.43% hold a college degree, 41.67% have a bachelor’s degree, 5.95% have a master’s degree, and 2.78% have a doctoral degree or above. The data analysis reveals that a relatively high proportion of respondents hold college and bachelor’s degrees. Among the surveyed individuals, 3.97% have less than 1 year of work experience, 17.46% have 1–3 years, 12.3% have 4–5 years, 14.29% have 6–8 years, 32.14% have 9–10 years, and 19.84% have more than 10 years. The data shows that a significant proportion of the surveyed individuals have relatively long work experience, which provides a certain degree of objectivity and comprehensiveness in reflecting the current safety status of prefabricated construction projects. Among the surveyed individuals, those who have little or no understanding of prefabricated buildings account for 14.68% of the total; those who have little or no understanding of safety resilience account for 14.29% of the total. This ensures the validity of the questionnaire to a certain extent.Finally, the quality of survey data was analyzed by examining the mean and standard deviation of the survey sample data.
Reliability Analysis.
Reliability analysis assesses the stability and precision of measurements. Using IBM SPSS Statistics 27.0(https://www.ibm.com/products/spss-statistics), the raw data were processed to calculate Cronbach’s alpha coefficient (α). The Cronbach’s Alpha exceeded the threshold of 0.7, confirming the high internal consistency reliability of the questionnaire data.
Confirmatory Factor Analysis.
The structural model linking latent constructs and observed variables was developed in IBM SPSS Amos29(https://www.spss.com/products/amos/) (illustrated in Fig. 1). After selecting data operations, confirmatory factor analysis is conducted based on construct validity, convergent validity, and discriminant validity.

sec.title: Bayesian network
sec.p: BN (Bayesian Network) stands as one of the most effective theoretical models for uncertain knowledge representation and probabilistic reasoning. In this study, we employ Bayesian networks to assess the safety resilience of prefabricated construction engineering systems. By conducting bidirectional reasoning analysis and sensitivity analysis using the established Bayesian network model, we ultimately identify key influencing factors.

sec.title: Establishment of bayesian network model structure
sec.p: After obtaining a “validated” measurement model structure, this study converts the CFA measurement model into a Bayesian network topology. In the BN structure, “Prefabricated Construction Engineering System Safety Resilience” is taken as the parent node in the BN, the observed resilience influencing factors are taken as the root nodes in the BN, the latent variable safety resilience index is taken as the intermediate node in the BN, and the paths from the latent variables to the observed indicators are taken as directed edges between nodes in the BN. Netica6.08 (https://www.norsys.com/netica.html) is used to establish the BN model structure, resulting in the BN topology diagram. In Bayesian network models, the direction of arcs between nodes is preset by existing theoretical literature. The statistical validation results of CFA support the validity of this theoretical assumption on this dataset, thus providing a statistical basis for transforming these measurement relationships into arcs in BN.This diagram precisely represents the interrelationships between the influencing factors within the indicator system and their corresponding resilience categories. The computational inference mechanism of the Bayesian Network reflects and propagates probabilistic relationships among the nodes.

sec.title: Determination of bayesian network model parameters
sec.p: Owing to the scarcity and limited accessibility of empirical data on safety resilience in prefabricated construction engineering systems, this study primarily employed an expert questionnaire survey. Expert knowledge and experience were leveraged to establish prior probabilities for root nodes and conditional probability tables (CPTs) for intermediate and leaf nodes within the Bayesian Network.Due to the strong professionalism of this survey questionnaire, the quality of the recipients is more important than the quantity of questionnaires distributed.Survey participants were strategically selected: Priority was given to frontline practitioners directly involved in prefabricated construction projects within contracting organizations.Senior professionals from project developers, design institutes, construction contractors, and supervision companies were also systematically consulted.

Of the 74 questionnaires distributed,27 were deemed invalid based primarily on inconsistent response patterns, supplemented by exclusion criteria of work experience under one year or insufficient domain-specific knowledge.Ultimately, 47 valid questionnaires were collected, with a response rate calculated as 63.51%, satisfying the empirical criterion of “having at least 5–10 observation samples under each parent node combination”.Among the 47 respondents surveyed, over two-thirds have more than four years of work experience, and over half are members of the management team of their respective organizations, meeting the quality requirements for questionnaire samples.Through statistical aggregation and expert evaluation of the collected data, Prior probabilities for all safety resilience influencing factors were determined. These priors were subsequently used to compute conditional probabilities for intermediate and leaf nodes.This empirically derived probability framework provides robust data support for subsequent analysis of safety resilience influence pathways.

sec.title: Identification of factors affecting the system safety resilience of prefabricated Building
sec.p: This study first summarized 37 factors affecting safety resilience through literature review and case analysis. Then, after two rounds of scoring using the Delphi method and statistical processing of the second scoring results, 13 indicators with an importance level below 3 were eliminated, resulting in 24 final factors affecting safety resilience in prefabricated building engineering systems.Guided by the theoretical framework of safety resilience, this research classifies the safety resilience of prefabricated building systems into four distinct categories: Predictive Resilience (PR), Responsive Resilience (RR), Fast Recovery Resilience (FR), Learning Resilience (LR).Finally, the influencing factors are systematically consolidated according to their identification dimension, specific manifestation, and corresponding resilience category, as comprehensively summarized in Table 1.

caption.p: Identification results of factors affecting safety resilience.

tr.td: On site management personnel and operators have sufficient safety awareness, are familiar with the operating procedures of mechanical equipment, and do not engage in any illegal operations

Has the on-site management personnel conducted acceptance checks on the entry and exit of large mechanical equipment, regularly inspected their operating status for safety, and carried out process maintenance in accordance with regulations
Acceptance, maintenance, and safety inspection of mechanical equipment
Do on-site management personnel regularly conduct safety inspections on material stacking
Are protective devices such as isolation barriers or safety warning signs installed in hazardous areas on site
Does the strength grade, geometric dimensions, load-bearing capacity, and deformation of prefabricated components comply with current national standards and actual construction needs
The rationality of prefabricated component design
Whether the safety main responsibility of the construction unit is fully implemented and whether they conscientiously fulfill their on-site operation safety management responsibilities
The completeness of the project safety production management system
Does the construction unit provide safety production education and training to the personnel on duty
Project safety production education and training
Has the construction unit conducted expert verification on specialized construction plans with significant risks beyond a certain scale
Expert demonstration of special construction plan
Whether the organizational structure, plan preparation, approval, drills, and evaluation work in the emergency rescue management of the construction unit are complete
The completeness of the project emergency rescue management system

Whether the construction plan layout of the construction unit is scientific and reasonable, and whether the meals, drinking water, and rest areas for employees and workers comply with relevant standards
Are on-site management personnel and operators wearing complete safety protection equipment when entering the construction site
Are the operators alert to potential danger signs and have the awareness and skills to self rescue or rescue others
Hazard awareness and rescue skills of homework personnel
Are the operators proficient in operating procedures, mastering construction techniques, and using mechanical equipment
The operational technical level of the homework personnel
Has the construction unit been equipped with necessary emergency rescue equipment and devices, including but not limited to firefighting equipment, rescue equipment, etc.
Emergency rescue equipment and equipment configuration for the project
Has the construction unit set up necessary safety protection facilities for parts that may have safety hazards, such as safety fences, safety nets, and protective sheds
Configuration of project safety protection facilities

Whether the communication of emergency response information for accidents is smooth, whether the prevention and control measures are appropriate, whether the aftermath is handled properly, and whether the emergency response for accidents is in place.
The completeness of the project emergency rescue plan
Have on-site special operation personnel received specialized safety operation training and obtained corresponding qualifications in accordance with regulations before taking up their posts
Qualification review of special operation personnel
During the construction process, whether the project safety management personnel have conducted thorough inspections of safety hazards, and whether they can promptly identify and eliminate them

Has the construction unit taken a series of measures to ensure the safety of the on-site and surrounding working environment, such as prevention and control of air, water, solid waste, noise and other pollution
Safety of on-site and surrounding work environment
Whether the homework personnel have strong psychological qualities, can timely control dangerous situations, prevent further expansion of casualties and losses
Whether the on-site management personnel have sufficient experience and ability to carry out subsequent rescue, rescue, and aftermath work
The experience and ability of management personnel
Can safety protection facilities in high-risk areas be quickly repaired or supplemented after a safety accident occurs to restore their safety status
Recovery rate of safety protection facilities
Can the construction unit increase the investment in safety and civilized construction fees targeted at weak links after a safety accident occurs
Targeted investment in safe and civilized construction costs

Can project management personnel and operators actively reflect on and learn from the experience and lessons after accidents occur, enhance their own safety awareness, in order to avoid future safety incidents
Self improvement of personnel safety awareness

sec.title: Confirmatory factor analysis of influencing factors
sec.p:
Based on the descriptive statistical results of this study, the average values of all influencing factors are above 3.0, with standard deviations ranging from 1.1 to 1.4. This indicates that all influencing factors are relatively important and there is no significant divergence, making them suitable as research subjects for subsequent analysis. According to the reliability analysis method, the Cronbach’s Alpha α obtained in this study is 0.937, which is greater than 0.7, indicating that the survey questionnaire data has good reliability. According to the confirmatory factor analysis method, the following validities are obtained:
Structural Validity.
Five indices were selected to evaluate the model fit between the hypothesized structure and observed data:χ²/df ratio (Chi-square/Degrees of Freedom), Goodness-of-Fit Index (GFI), Comparative Fit Index (CFI), Adjusted Goodness-of-Fit Index (AGFI), Root Mean Square Error of Approximation (RMSEA).These metrics collectively verify the theoretical plausibility and empirical validity of the model, ensuring the robustness and methodological rigor of the findings. Computational results are presented in Table 2.
Table 2
Fitting results of the confirmatory factor analysis model.
Fitting indicatorsAnalysis resultReference rangeAdaptability assessment
χ²/df1.49< 2Good effect
GFI0.892Approaching 0.9Basically acceptable
CFI0.967> 0.95Acceptable
AGFI0.869Approaching 0.9Basically acceptable
RMSEA0.044< 0.05Ideal
As indicated in the table above: The χ²/df ratio is 1.49 (< 2), indicating good model fit. RMSEA is 0.044 (< 0.05), demonstrating excellent fit. GFI is 0.892 (approaching 0.90), rendering the result marginally acceptable. CFI is 0.967 (> 0.95), confirming an acceptable fit. AGFI is 0.869 (approaching 0.90), suggesting a marginally acceptable fit. Collectively, these model fit indices confirm that the proposed Confirmatory Factor Analysis (CFA) model exhibits satisfactory goodness-of-fit and is statistically acceptable.
Convergent validity.
Standardized factor loadings for latent constructs on their respective observed variables are presented in Table 3.
Table 3
Factor load table.
RouteEstimateAVECR
PRR1<---Predicting resilience0.8210.6450.948
PRJ1<---Predicting resilience0.79
PRW1<---Predicting resilience0.84
PRW2<---Predicting resilience0.833
PRW3<---Predicting resilience0.791
PRF1<---Predicting resilience0.784
PRF2<---Predicting resilience0.788
PRF3<---Predicting resilience0.81
PRF4<---Predicting resilience0.792
PRH1<---Predicting resilience0.778
RRR1<---Response resilience0.7420.5730.924
RRR2<---Response resilience0.799
RRR3<---Response resilience0.732
RRW1<---Response resilience0.727
RRW2<---Response resilience0.744
RRF1<---Response resilience0.735
RRF2<---Response resilience0.782
RRF3<---Response resilience0.802
RRH1<---Response resilience0.746
FRR1<---Quickly restore resilience0.8140.6290.871
FRR2<---Quickly restore resilience0.813
FRW1<---Quickly restore resilience0.772
FRF1<---Quickly restore resilience0.771
LRR1<---Learning resilience0.8220.6270.771
As indicated in the table above: Factor loadings between each latent construct (Predictive Resilience, Responsive Resilience, Fast Recovery Resilience, and Learning Resilience) and their corresponding observed variables exceed 0.7, demonstrating strong correlations and alignment between the observed variables and their underlying constructs. This reveals robust intrinsic relationships. Additionally, the AVE (Average Variance Extracted) for all latent constructs exceeds 0.5, while CR (Composite Reliability) values are above or approach 0.8. These results collectively confirm excellent convergent validity of the measurement scale.
Discriminant Validity.
To determine whether the latent constructs exhibit adequate discriminant validity, a comparative table of AVE values and inter-construct correlation coefficients was calculated, as presented in Table 4.
Table 4
Comparison of AVE and correlation coefficient.
Predicting resilienceResponse resilienceQuickly restore resilienceLearning resilience
Predicting resilience0.645
Response resilience0.343**0.573
Quickly restore resilience0.384**0.248**0.629
Learning resilience0.391**0.2**0.236**0.627
AVE square root0.8030.7570.7930.792
**Represents a p-value less than 0.01; The diagonal represents the AVE evaluation variance variation extraction quantity.
As demonstrated in the table above: A statistically significant correlation exists among the latent constructs of Predictive Resilience, Responsive Resilience, Fast Recovery Resilience, and Learning Resilience (*p* < 0.01). Furthermore, the absolute values of correlation coefficients are all below 0.5 and are less than the square roots of their corresponding Average Variance Extracted (AVE) values. For instance, examining Responsive Resilience: its correlation coefficients (0.248 and 0.2) are both below 0.5 and less than its corresponding AVE square root (AVE = 0.757). These results collectively indicate that the latent constructs exhibit moderate inter-correlations while maintaining sufficient discriminant validity. Thus, the measurement model demonstrates highly satisfactory discriminant validity.

In summary, to assess whether the observed data align with the hypothesized theoretical model, a Confirmatory Factor Analysis (CFA) model was constructed to evaluate structural validity, convergent validity, and discriminant validity. The results confirm that the proposed safety resilience indicator system for prefabricated construction engineering systems is methodologically sound. This validation enhances the accuracy and reliability of the research findings and provides a robust measurement instrument and theoretical framework for subsequent investigations.

sec.title: Construction of bayesian network model
sec.p: Using “Prefabricated Construction Engineering System Safety Resilience” as the parent node, the 24 key resilience influencing factors filtered from the previous text as the root nodes, and the four subordinate resilience factors, namely “Predictive Resilience (PR)”, “Response Resilience (RR)”, “Fast Recovery Resilience (FR)”, and “Learning Resilience (LR)”, as intermediate nodes, a Bayesian network model structure is constructed. The safety resilience influencing factors are divided into two states: effective and ineffective, represented by “Yes” and “No” respectively. Using the method of determining Bayesian network model parameters, the prior probabilities of the safety resilience influencing factors are obtained, as shown in Table 5.

caption.p: Prior probabilities of factors affecting safety resilience.

sec.p: Based on the obtained prior probabilities, calculate the conditional probability tables of intermediate nodes and leaf nodes through formulas. Taking the causal relationship of factors affecting rapid recovery resilience as an example, rapid recovery resilience is divided into two states: effective and ineffective, represented by “Yes” and “No” respectively. The specific calculation results of their conditional probabilities are shown in Table 6.

caption.p: Probability table of “rapid recovery resilience” conditions for intermediate nodes.

sec.title: Bayesian network security resilience prior probability analysis
sec.p: In the Netica 6.08(https://www.norsys.com/netica.html), edit the states of each node. For instance, the state indicating whether a safety resilience-influencing factor is active can be represented by two options: “Yes” for active and “No” for inactive. After creating all nodes, input the prior probability parameters derived from questionnaire analysis. Once data entry is complete, utilize the Netica 6.08(https://www.norsys.com/netica.html) to compute the probabilities for each node within the model, resulting in a prior probability diagram.The prior probability diagram indicates that within the constructed Bayesian network, the predicted resilience (PR) of the prefabricated building construction system has a probability of 51.0% of being active. The response resilience (RR) has a probability of 48.6% of being active, the rapid recovery resilience (FR) has a probability of 69.1% of being active, and the learning resilience (LR) has a probability of 69.2% of being active. The overall safety resilience of the prefabricated building construction system has a probability of 65.6% of being active.

Analysis of the prior probability results indicates that the current operational level of safety resilience within existing prefabricated building construction systems is relatively low. Among the four resilience dimensions, rapid recovery resilience (FR) and learning resilience (LR) demonstrate relatively commendable performance. Conversely, response resilience (RR) exhibits the lowest probability of being active (48.6%), signifying that the system’s resistance capability requires the most significant enhancement.This suggests that, at the current stage, when risk disturbances occur during the implementation of prefabricated building construction, the site demonstrates an ability to respond swiftly to emergent hazardous situations, conduct repairs, and restore work areas to normal operations rapidly. However, the system’s capacity to resist incidents and disasters is weak; it fails to effectively withstand initial impacts. Consequently, enhancements to the system’s robustness, redundancy, and managerial agility are imperative.Furthermore, the probability of predicted resilience (PR) being active is also comparatively low (51.0%). This implies that the system inadequately perceives changes in its internal and external environment. Its ability to proactively identify vulnerabilities within subsystems prior to the occurrence of natural disasters or safety incidents, and implement preemptive protective measures to mitigate the likelihood or severity of system damage, is insufficient.

Analysis of the intermediate nodes reveals the following within the Predicted Resilience (PR) module, The probability of the root node PRW1 being active is 40.7%. This indicates inadequate on-site inspection of material storage practices, necessitating regular checks of materials awaiting use.The probability of PRF3 being active is only 35.5%. This signifies insufficient crisis awareness among project management personnel, resulting in a failure to strictly conduct mandatory expert reviews for specially designated construction plans involving significant hazards beyond a certain scale, as stipulated by regulations.The probability of PRF4 being active is 49.3%. This points to inadequate implementation of policies concerning the improvement of emergency rescue management systems within project departments. Consequently, prompt rescue and response efforts cannot be initiated immediately following a safety incident.However, the probability of PRR1 being active is significantly high at 92.8%. This demonstrates that all construction units place strong emphasis on fostering safety awareness among both management and operational personnel.

Analysis within the Response Resilience (RR) module reveals the following, The probability of the root node RRR3 being active is only 35.0%. This indicates that the technical proficiency of on-site operational personnel requires improvement, as a significant proportion of safety incidents stem from workers’ unfamiliarity with operating machinery and equipment.The probability of RRW2 being active is merely 33.6%. This signifies insufficient investment by construction units in safety protection facilities, which severely endangers the lives of on-site workers and inspection personnel.Calculation results demonstrate that the probabilities of influencing factors being active across the system’s response resilience are generally not high. This indicates room for improvement to varying degrees in all aspects of the system’s capacity to resist risks.
Analysis of Rapid Recovery (FR) and Learning (LR) Resilience Modules.

The overall probabilities of factors being active within both the Rapid Recovery Resilience (FR) and Learning Resilience (LR) modules are generally adequate.Notably, the probability of the root node FRR2 being active is 59.4%. This further underscores the critical importance of on-site management personnel’s experience and competence – specifically, their ability to effectively organize and execute subsequent rescue, relief, and post-incident recovery operations following accident damage.

Overall, the probabilities of PRR1, PRF2, and FRF1 being active exceed 80%. This indicates that significant attention is currently being paid by construction units to the following factors during prefabricated building construction: personnel safety awareness, project-specific safety production education and training, and targeted investment in safe and civilized construction practices. However, the probability values for the activation of the remaining root nodes in the network fall within the range of 50–80%. This signifies that considerable room for improvement exists for numerous safety resilience influencing factors within the prefabricated building construction process.

sec.title: Analysis of posterior probability diagnostic reasoning in bayesian networks
sec.p: The functionality of Bayesian networks in diagnostic reasoning lies in their capacity to inferentially calculate the probability of occurrence for each node. This is achieved by analyzing the impact of the known probability of a specific node occurring on the probability changes of other related nodes, demonstrating their efficacy in providing decision support under uncertain conditions. This tool enables reverse inference, tracing from known outcomes back to potential causes. It is extensively applied in critical domains such as risk quantification, intelligent decision-making, and anomaly detection. Through iterative feedback and refinement, users can significantly enhance model performance, thereby furnishing more precise and reliable data support for the decision-making process. For instance, in the Netica 6.08(https://www.norsys.com/netica.html), setting the probability of the “not activated” state for leaf nodes to 100% yields the posterior probability maps.

In the Predictive Resilience (PR) module, when the probability of failure for the safety resilience of the prefabricated construction engineering system is set to 100%, the probability of failure for the safety inspection of material stacking at location PRW1 increased from 59.3 to 62.7%, representing a 3.4% increase. This node exhibited the largest magnitude change within the module, signifying that it demonstrates the highest volatility among all assessed parameters. These changes in probability values indicate this node is the most unstable contributor in the system.This analysis demonstrates that enhancing the frequency of regular safety inspections for material stacking constitutes a highly effective preventive measure for both identifying potential hazards and mitigating associated risks, enabling the proactive forecasting of potential safety incidents. To effectively manage this critical vulnerability, project leadership should Intensify the frequency of routine safety production meetings and heighten safety awareness among personnel responsible for safety management and material handling.In addition, project leaders should implement standardized and regular inspection protocols for the storage conditions of all delivered materials.

In the Response Resilience (RR) module, when the probability of failure for the safety resilience of the prefabricated construction engineering system is set to 100%, the probability of failureassociated with the operational skill level of workers at location RRR3 increased from 65.0 to 66.1%. This represents an increase of 1.1% points and constitutes the most significant probabilistic variation observed among all nodes within this module.This finding underscores that enhancing the operational skill level of the workforce presents a critical challenge. Insufficient proficiency coupled with a lack of experience in handling diverse contingencies substantially elevates the risk of precipitating mechanical hazardsduring practical operations.To address this vulnerability, project management must mandate strict compliance from subcontractors responsible for prefabricated component manufacturing and on-site personnel by ensuring Comprehensive development and implementation of standard operating procedures (SOPs) for every piece of heavy machinery and rigorous verification that all workers demonstrate thorough mastery and consistent application of these procedures.

In the Fast Recovery (FR) module, when the probability of failure for the safety resilience of the prefabricated construction engineering system is set to 100%, the probability of failureassociated with the psychological resilience of workers at location FRR1 increased from 30.7 to 33.0%. This represents a rise of 2.3% points, constituting the most substantial probabilistic shift observed among all nodes within this module.The psychological resilience of the workforce—specifically, their capacity to promptly control hazardous situations and prevent escalation of casualties and losses—is a critical determinantin whether the project can achieve timely recovery from risk disruptions. Consequently, enhancing workers’ psychological resilience yields significant improvements in overall system resilience. This necessitates implementing specialized skill training and psychological counseling for workers during the initial phases of engineering projects.Given that human factors represent the paramount element in management systems, it is imperative to effectively mobilize all human resources. Resilience building must transcend traditional top-down approaches by activating the subjective initiative of every worker. This requires a dual focus Training in operational competencies and cultivating risk response capabilities.This dual strategy ensures that frontline personnel encountering emergent hazards can rapidly curb the propagation of risks.

In the Learning Resilience (LR) module, when the probability of failure for the safety resilience of the prefabricated construction engineering system is set to 100%, the probability of failureassociated with the proactive enhancement of personnel safety awareness at location LRR1 increased from 33.0 to 39.8%, representing a significant rise of 6.8% points.Consequently, the proactive enhancement of safety awareness constitutes the most direct mechanism for improving learning resilience. This process requires both project management personnel and operational workers to critically reflect on incidents following safety events, internalize lessons learned, and implement corrective measures to prevent recurrence of similar safety incidents, thereby systematically strengthening organizational learning resilience.

sec.title: Sensitivity analysis of predictive resilience
sec.p: According to Table 7, the sensitivity of the 10 safety resilience influencing factors in predicting resilience is as follows: PRW1> PRF3> PRF1> PRH1> PRW2> PRJ1> PRF4> PRF2> PRW3> PRR1, That is, its impact on predicting toughness PR decreases in order. Therefore, the factors that exert the greatest influence on predicting resilience are the safety inspection of PRW1 material stacking and the expert review of the PRF3 special construction plan. OSHA (Occupational Safety and Health Administration in the United States), HSE (Health and Safety Executive in the United Kingdom), and China’s “Standard for Safety Management of Construction Site” all provide extensive details on the requirements for stacking height, spacing, and support of various materials (such as steel bars, blocks, and formwork). The existence of these mandatory provisions is itself an acknowledgment by the industry of the high importance of the risk point of “material stacking”. Elevating the “PRW1” node from an analytical variable to the level of mandatory enforcement by regulations demonstrates its fundamental status. Standards worldwide (such as China’s “Regulations on Safety Management of High-Risk Divisional and Sub-divisional Works”) all mandate the preparation of specialized construction plans and the organization of expert demonstrations. The regulations explicitly make “expert demonstration” a prerequisite for the commencement of such projects, which directly confirms that “expert demonstration of specialized construction plans (PRF3)” is a key decision node in preventing systemic collapse. Therefore, it is highly reasonable to consider PRW1 (safety inspection of material stacking) and PRF3 (expert demonstration of specialized construction plans) as the most critical root nodes for predicting safety resilience.The project department should place special emphasis on material management and the review of construction plans for sub-divisional works with high risks, in order to mitigate safety risks at their source.

caption.p: Sensitivity analysis results of predicting resilience PR nodes.

tr.th: Coefficient of variation of correlation index

sec.title: Sensitivity analysis of response resilience
sec.p: According to Table 8, the sensitivity of the 9 safety resilience influencing factors in response resilience RR is as follows: RRR3 > RRW2 > RRF2 > RRH1 > RRW1 > RRR1 > RRF3 > RRF1 > RRR2, indicating that their impact on response resilience RR decreases in order. The factors that have the greatest impact on response resilience are the operational skill level of RRR3 operators and the configuration of safety protection facilities for RRW2 projects. In human factors engineering and resilience engineering, “human skills” and “adaptive capacity” are repeatedly emphasized as the cornerstones of system responsiveness. Numerous studies have demonstrated that humans are the most flexible and intelligent element in the response process, and their technical proficiency directly determines the quality and speed of response actions. Furthermore, safety protection facilities serve as physical barriers that absorb energy, isolate hazards, and buy time for human response, forming the “material foundation” of response resilience. They provide crucial fault tolerance space and are a prerequisite for the system to bounce back from disturbances. Therefore, RRR3 (human) represents the “active core” of response resilience, while RRW2 (physical) represents the “passive cornerstone” of response resilience. It is highly reasonable to consider these two factors as the most critical in influencing response resilience.The project department must simultaneously enhance the development of personnel and increase investment in resources to maximize the project’s emergency response capability.

caption.p: Sensitivity analysis results of response resilience RR nodes.

tr.th: Coefficient of variation of correlation index

sec.title: Sensitivity analysis of rapid recovery resilience
sec.p: According to Table 9, the sensitivity of the four factors affecting safety resilience in rapid recovery resilience is FRR1 > FRW1 > FRR2 > FRF1, indicating that their impact on rapid recovery resilience FR decreases in order. The most significant factor influencing the rapid recovery of resilience is the psychological quality of FRR1 operators. Previous research on resilience restoration has emphasized more on hardware repair, resource scheduling, process optimization, etc. This study innovatively proposes that “the psychological quality of personnel is a more important ‘catalyst’ than hardware, technology, or even contingency plans.” Because the psychological state of personnel is the “software” and “operating system” that initiates and accelerates all physical restoration work. Ensuring “psychological safety” and “mental health” is the prerequisite for carrying out any effective physical restoration, which echoes the core viewpoint of disaster psychology. The judgment or choice made by a worker with good psychological quality in an emergency situation is crucial for promptly controlling the dangerous situation and preventing it from escalating further.Therefore, FRR1 (the psychological quality of operating personnel) is the most critical factor affecting rapid resilience restoration—a very advanced and reasonable conclusion. While enterprises focus on processes and hardware, they must also invest in the inner strength of people.

caption.p: Sensitivity analysis results of fast recovery resilience FR nodes.

tr.th: Coefficient of variation of correlation index

sec.title: Sensitivity analysis of learning resilience
sec.p: According to Table 10, it is evident that the factor with the greatest impact on learning resilience is the self-improvement of LRR1 personnel’s safety awareness. Leading industry practice reports repeatedly emphasize that the core of the shift from “compliance-based” security to “proactive” security culture lies in stimulating individual initiative. Learning from accidents, cultivating employees’ self-awareness of safety, and being able to correctly recognize and handle safety risks are the keys to safety education and management.Therefore, it is reasonable to assert that LRR1 (self-improvement of personnel security awareness) is the most critical factor affecting learning resilience. Investing in human awareness is the soul of building sustainable security capabilities and the cornerstone for achieving the highest level of resilience.

caption.p: Sensitivity analysis results of learning resilience LR nodes.

tr.th: Coefficient of variation of correlation index

sec.title: Sensitivity analysis of systems safety resilience for prefabricated Building
sec.p: According to Table 11, the sensitivity of the four types of resilience in the safety resilience SR of prefabricated building engineering systems is PR > LR > RR > FR, indicating that their impact on the safety resilience SR of prefabricated building engineering systems decreases in order. The sensitivity of predicting resilience PR is the highest, which means its impact on the safety resilience SR of prefabricated building engineering systems is the greatest.Traditional cast-in-place construction allows for extensive adjustments and modifications on-site, whereas the components of prefabricated buildings, once completed in the factory, have fixed dimensions, joints, embedded parts, etc. If design conflicts or lifting point issues are discovered on-site, they are almost impossible to resolve on the spot and can only be returned to the factory or scrapped, resulting in significant losses and safety risks. The unique “front-end decision-making, back-end execution” model of prefabricated buildings determines that their safety performance is almost “predestined” before construction begins. In traditional cast-in-place buildings, the weight of “response toughness” may be relatively high, while prefabricated buildings rely more on “prediction.” Therefore, in prefabricated building projects, the impact of predictive toughness (PR) on the overall system safety toughness (SR) is of great rationality and practical significance.Project decision-makers should allocate more resources and energy to safety reviews during the design phase, in-depth argumentation of construction plans, and strict control over the supply chain, to achieve a strategic transformation from “passive response” to “active foresight”. Only in this way can the overall safety resilience of the project be maximized. Furthermore, prefabricated construction enterprises should regard predictive resilience as the core pillar of modernizing their safety management systems, viewing it as an important strategic investment rather than a mere cost expenditure.

caption.p: Sensitivity analysis results of safety resilience SR for prefabricated Building engineering systems.

tr.th: Coefficient of variation of correlation index

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: To enhance the system safety resilience of prefabricated construction projects, this study identified 24 influencing factors of system safety resilience in prefabricated buildings through literature review, case analysis, and Delphi method, and conducted a confirmatory factor analysis on these factors. Based on the results of the factor analysis, a Bayesian network model structure was established, and a sensitivity analysis was conducted on the influencing factors to identify key influencing factors. Based on the results and discussion, the following conclusions were drawn:

list-item.p: To enhance predictive resilience, the project department should prioritize safety inspections of material stacking and expert verification of specialized construction plans. Regarding safety inspections of material stacking, the project department should establish a management organizational system and management regulations, clarify responsible entities and job responsibilities, arrange full-time safety management personnel to conduct on-site inspections according to safety management regulations, and track and recheck potential safety hazards throughout the entire process. For expert verification of specialized construction plans, it is necessary to strictly control the expert members, approval, and execution processes of the verification, ensuring that the content of the specialized plan is complete and feasible, that the calculation sheets, verification bases, and construction drawings in the specialized plan comply with standards and specifications, and that the specialized construction plan can fit the actual situation on site.

To enhance response resilience, the focus should be on the operational skill level of workers and the configuration of project safety protection facilities. To improve the operational skill level of workers, the project department should attach importance to pre-job training and continuing education, allowing workers to be familiar with laws and regulations, technical standards, and normative documents, and to master various safety operation procedures and protective measures. At the same time, dynamic safety supervision should be implemented in combination with information technology such as the Internet of Things. For project safety protection facilities, the construction of prefabricated building projects and the construction of safety protection facilities should be carried out simultaneously and strictly implemented. In the event of a safety accident, safety protection facilities will minimize the casualty rate and direct economic losses to the greatest extent;

To enhance the resilience of rapid recovery, it is crucial to focus on improving the psychological quality of the operating personnel. The project department can regularly organize emergency drills for various risk scenarios and invite technical personnel or safety experts with rich operational experience to demonstrate on site, Regularly conduct psychological resilience training and stress test simulations, strengthen psychological construction, and calmly respond to unexpected risks.

To enhance learning resilience, it is crucial to focus on the self-improvement of personnel’s safety awareness. The project department should enhance workers’ safety awareness and alertness to potential risks. In practical work, workers should be encouraged to proactively identify hazards or conduct risk assessments for their work.

sec.p: Based on the theory of safety resilience, this study enriches the dimensions of safety management research in prefabricated construction engineering and provides new ideas for analyzing and effectively controlling safety risks in prefabricated buildings. However, there are still limitations in the research. (1)given the challenges of data collection in prefabricated construction projects, this study adopted the method of designing a questionnaire to estimate the parameters required to construct a Bayesian network. This process is inevitably constrained by the personal biases of experts. In future research, integrating historical monitoring data will enable a more precise evaluation of resilience indicators, thus providing a more objective and comprehensive quantitative method.(2)Although the BN structure in this study is grounded in a robust theoretical framework, the causal relationships it presents are primarily theory-driven, rather than purely data-driven. The role of CFA is to verify that observed variables can reliably represent underlying concepts, thus laying a solid foundation for constructing the BN model. Future research could collect data at different time points to more rigorously test these causal paths, or employ experimental methods to manipulate key variables to provide stronger causal evidence.
